The '''Agricultural Act of 2014''' ({{USBill|113|hr|2642}}; {{USPL|113|79}}, also known as the '''2014 U.S. Farm Bill'''), formerly the "Federal Agriculture Reform and Risk Management Act of 2013", is an [[act of Congress]] that [[Authorization bill|authorize]]s nutrition and agriculture programs in the United States for the years of 2014-2018.<ref name=cbo2642long>{{cite web|title=CBO - H.R. 2642 conference version|url=http://www.cbo.gov/sites/default/files/cbofiles/attachments/hr2642LucasLtr.pdf|publisher=Congressional Budget Office|accessdate=29 January 2014}}</ref> The bill authorizes $956 billion in spending over the next ten years.<ref name="Hpass956B"/>
The bill passed in the [[United States House of Representatives]] on January 29, 2014, and the [[United States Senate]] on February 4, 2014 during the [[113th United States Congress]]. U.S. President [[Barack Obama]] signed the bill into law on February 7, 2014. The bill is considered two years late, since farm bills are traditionally passed every five years.<ref name=bernstein29>{{cite news|last=Bernstein|first=Jonathan|title=Farm Bill Proves Politics Isn't Dead. Yet|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2014-01-29/farm-bill-proves-politics-isn-t-dead-yet-.html|accessdate=29 January 2014|newspaper=Bloomberg|date=29 January 2014}}</ref> The previous farm bill, [[Food, Conservation, and Energy Act of 2008]], expired in 2012.<ref name="PlumerWashPost"/>
==Background==
===Farm bills=== {{main|United States farm bill}}
In the United States, the '''farm bill''' is the primary [[Agricultural policy in the United States|agricultural and food policy tool]] of the [[federal government of the United States|federal government]]. The comprehensive [[omnibus bill]] is passed every five years or so by the [[United States Congress]] and deals with both agriculture and all other affairs under the purview of the [[United States Department of Agriculture]]. It usually makes amendments and suspensions to provisions of permanent law, reauthorizes, amends, or repeals provisions of preceding temporary agricultural acts, and puts forth new policy provisions for a limited time into the future. Beginning in 1973, farm bills have included titles on commodity programs, trade, rural development, farm credit, conservation, agricultural research, food and nutrition programs, marketing, etc.<ref name="CRS">[http://ncseonline.org/nle/crsreports/05jun/97-905.pdf CRS Report for Congress: Agriculture: A Glossary of Terms, Programs, and Laws, 2005 Edition – Order Code 97-905] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110212033139/http://ncseonline.org/nle/crsreports/05jun/97-905.pdf |date=2011-02-12 }},</ref> Farm bills can be highly controversial and can impact [[international trade]], [[natural environment|environmental]] conservation, [[food safety]], and the well-being of [[rural communities]]. The [[agricultural subsidy]] programs mandated by the farm bills are the subject of intense debate both within the U.S. and internationally.
The farm bill was first created during the [[Great Depression]] to give financial assistance to farmers who were struggling due to an excess crop supply creating low prices, and also to control and ensure an adequate food supply.<ref name=Crissman>{{cite news |title=Senate approves new farm bill |author=Alison Crissman |url=http://www.dailyiowan.com/2013/06/12/Metro/33464.html |work=[[The Daily Iowan]] |date=12 June 2013 |accessdate=18 June 2013}}</ref> The first farm bill, known as the [[Agriculture Adjustment Act]] (AAA), was passed by Congress in 1933 as a part of [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]]'s [[New Deal]].<ref name=Neuman>{{cite news |title=Why The Farm Bill's Provisions Will Matter To You |author=Scott Neuman |url=https://www.npr.org/2012/06/13/154862017/why-the-farm-bills-provisions-will-matter-to-you |work=[[NPR]] |date=13 June 2013 |accessdate=18 June 2013}}</ref> The [[Food, Conservation, and Energy Act of 2008]] is the most recent farm bill, prior to this one.
==Provisions of the bill== The bill includes cuts to [[Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program]] (SNAP), commonly known as "food stamps".<ref name=nytNixonHapproves>{{cite news|last=Nixon|first=Ron|title=House Approves Farm Bill, Ending 2-Year Impasse|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/01/30/us/politics/house-approves-farm-bill-ending-2-year-impasse.html?_r=0|accessdate=29 January 2014|newspaper=The New York Times|date=29 January 2014}}</ref> According to ''[[The New York Times]]'', the $8 billion in cuts will mean that 850,000 households will lose $90/month in benefits.<ref name="nytNixonHapproves"/> However, the bill increases funding to food banks by $200 million.<ref name="nytNixonHapproves"/> SNAP is the largest portion of spending in the bill.<ref name="PlumerWashPost"/> The $8 billion in cuts comes from setting a minimum of $20 per year for the Low Income Home Energy Assistance Program (LIHEAP) to receive the Standard Utility Allowance (SUA) deduction, disallow [[medical marijuana]] as a deduction and ruling that lottery winners and persons convicted of certain crimes (murder, aggravated sexual abuse, [[sexual assault]], and sexual exploitation and other abuse of children) can't get food stamps.<ref>Agricultural Act of 2014: Sections 4005-4009</ref> However, the bill would start a new pilot program to encourage people on food stamps to try to find jobs.<ref name="PlumerWashPost"/>
The bill places income caps on farm subsidies, has a price support program for dairy farmers and ends direct payment subsidies, which paid farmers whether or not they actually grew any crops.<ref name="nytNixonHapproves"/> This subsidy had cost $5 billion a year.<ref name="nytNixonHapproves"/> The bill also removes federal restrictions aimed at growing [[industrial hemp]] and allows any states that have legalized its manufacturing to set up research programs to study the benefits of cultivating it.<ref>{{cite news|last=Campbell|first=Greg|date=8 February 2014|title=Farm bill clears the way for hemp production|url=http://dailycaller.com/2014/02/08/farm-bill-clears-the-way-for-hemp-production/|newspaper=The Daily Caller|accessdate=26 March 2014}}</ref> The Agricultural Act of 2014 also contained the [[Christmas Tree Research and Promotion Order]], a [[commodity checkoff program]] that established the [[Christmas Tree Promotion Board]].<ref name=usda14>"[http://www.ams.usda.gov/AMSv1.0/ams.fetchTemplateData.do?template=TemplateU&navID=LatestReleases&page=Newsroom&topNav=Newsroom&leftNav=&rightNav1=LatestReleases&rightNav2=&resultType=Details&dDocName=STELPRDC5106950&dID=197485&wf=false&description=As+Required+by+New+Farm+Bill%2C+USDA+to+Allow+Christmas+Tree+Research+and+Promotion+Program+to+Move+Forward+ As Required by New Farm Bill, USDA to Allow Christmas Tree Research and Promotion Program to Move Forward]", press release, ''[[United States Department of Agriculture]]'', Agricultural Marketing Service, April 4, 2014, accessed November 19, 2014.</ref>
===Spending=== According to [[Brad Plumer]] at ''[[The Washington Post]]'', the spending in the bill (FY 2014-2023) breaks down in the following manner:<ref name=PlumerWashPost>{{cite news|last=Plumer|first=Brad|title=The $956 billion farm bill, in one graph|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/wonkblog/wp/2014/01/28/the-950-billion-farm-bill-in-one-chart/|accessdate=29 January 2014|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=28 January 2014}}</ref>
{|class="wikitable" ! Area !! Amount |- | Food stamps and nutrition || $756 billion |- | Crop insurance || $89.8 billion |- | Conservation || $56 billion |- | Commodity programs || $44.4 billion |- | Everything else || $8.2 billion |}
In total, this spending represents about 2.1% of projected federal spending over that time period.<ref>{{cite web|title=An Update to the Budget and Economic Outlook: 2014 to 2024|url=http://www.cbo.gov/publication/45653|date=27 August 2014|publisher=Congressional Budget Office|accessdate=27 November 2014}}</ref>
==Congressional Budget Office report== [[File:Congressional Budget Office's report on the Agriculture Act of 2014.pdf|thumb|left|Effects on direct spending and revenues of the conference agreement on H.R. 2642, as reported on January 27, 2014.]]
''This summary is based largely on the summary provided by the [[Congressional Budget Office]] about the effects on direct spending and revenues of the conference agreement on H.R. 2642, as reported on January 27, 2014. This is a [[public domain]] source.''<ref name=2642cbo>{{cite web|title=H.R. 2642 - CBO|url=http://www.cbo.gov/publication/45049|publisher=Congressional Budget Office|accessdate=29 January 2014}}</ref>
The [[Congressional Budget Office]] (CBO) estimates that direct spending stemming from the programs authorized by the conference agreement would total $956 billion over the 2014-2023 period, of which $756 billion would be for nutrition programs.<ref name="2642cbo"/> Relative to spending and revenues projected under the CBO’s May 2013 baseline, the CBO estimates that enacting the conference agreement would lower budget deficits by $16.6 billion over that 10-year period.<ref name="2642cbo"/> The CBO reported that original House version, [[Federal Agriculture Reform and Risk Management Act of 2013 (H.R. 1947; 113th Congress)]], would have reduced direct spending by $51.8 billion and increased revenues by $60 million.<ref name="cbo2642long"/> The original Senate version, [[Agriculture Reform, Food, and Jobs Act of 2013 (S. 954; 113th Congress)]], would have decreased direct spending by $17.7 billion and increased revenues by $50 million.<ref name="cbo2642long"/>
Most spending under the legislation would stem from provisions regarding nutrition (title IV), crop insurance (title XI), commodity programs (title I), and conservation programs (title II).<ref name="2642cbo"/>
Title I - Commodities. CBO estimates that enacting title I would reduce spending on commodity programs by $14.3 billion over the 2014-2023 period, $3 billion to $4 billion less than under the House- and Senate- passed bills. The conference agreement, as well as both the House and Senate bills, would end fixed payments and certain other existing forms of price and income support to producers. They would all establish new programs that would require producers to choose between price supports or a guarantee of some of their expected revenue.<ref name="cbo2642long"/>
Title IV - Nutrition. Title IV of the conference agreement would reduce nutrition spending by $8 billion over the 2014-2023 period, CBO estimates. The House-passed bill would reduce such spending by $39 billion over the 10-year period. It includes two provisions not contained in the conference agreement that would reduce spending on the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) by restricting the definition of categorical eligibility for the program and reducing the number of waivers from work requirements available for certain adult SNAP recipients. The Senate-passed bill would reduce nutrition spending by $4 billion over the next 10 years, about half the reduction in the conference agreement. It contains a proposal to limit heating and cooling allowances for SNAP participants that is less restrictive than the provision include in the conference agreement.<ref name="cbo2642long"/>
Title XI - Crop Insurance. The conference agreement's provisions on crop insurance would increase costs by $5.7 billion over the 2014-2023 period, CBO estimates. Total spending for crop insurance over the 2014-2023 period would increase by about $9 billion under the House-passed legislation and by about $5 billion under the Senate-passed legislation.<ref name="cbo2642long"/>
This estimate does not include the additional discretionary spending for agricultural programs that would result from implementing the conference agreement; such spending would be subject to future appropriation actions. CBO also has not reviewed the conference agreement for intergovernmental or private-sector mandates.<ref name="2642cbo"/>
==Procedural history== [[File:Agricultural Act of 2014 Conference Report to Accompany H.R. 2642.pdf|thumb|right|Agricultural Act of 2014 Conference Report to Accompany H.R. 2642]]
===Legislation in 2013=== The Federal Agriculture Reform and Risk Management Act of 2013 (version H.R. 2642) was introduced into the [[United States House of Representatives]] on July 10, 2013 by [[Frank Lucas (Oklahoma)|Rep. Frank Lucas (R-OK)]], the chairman of the [[United States House Committee on Agriculture]].<ref name=2642allactions>{{cite web|title=H.R. 2642 - All Actions|url=http://beta.congress.gov/bill/113th-congress/house-bill/2642/all-actions/|publisher=United States Congress|accessdate=29 January 2014}}</ref> The bill was referred to that committee. On July 11, 2013, the House voted in [http://clerk.house.gov/evs/2013/roll353.xml Roll Call Vote 353] to pass the bill 216-208, after several failed attempts were made to delay or amend the bill.<ref name="2642allactions"/> The [[United States Senate]] received the bill on July 16, 2013. On July 18, 2013, the Senate voted to amend the bill by replacing most of it with language from their proposed farm bill, the [[Agriculture Reform, Food, and Jobs Act of 2013 (S. 954; 113th Congress)]]. The amended bill passed the Senate by [[unanimous consent]] on July 18, 2013 and the Senate requested a conference with the House on the bill. The Senate selected Senators Stabenow, Leahy, Harkin, Baucus, Brown, Klobuchar, Bennet, Cochran, Chambliss, Roberts, Boozman, and Hoeven as their conferees.<ref name="2642allactions"/>
===Conference committee=== Eventually, on October 12, 2013, the House agreed to a conference on the bill and conferees were chosen: * [[Steve Southerland (Florida politician)|Steve Southerland]] (R-FL) * [[Marcia Fudge]] (D-OH) * [[Dave Camp]] (R-OH) * [[Sam Johnson]] (R-TX) * [[Sander Levin]] (D-Mich.) * [[Ed Royce]] (R-CA) * [[Tom Marino]] (R-PA.) * [[Eliot Engel]] (D-NY) * [[Frank Lucas (Oklahoma legislator)|Frank Lucas]] (R-OK) * [[Steve King]] (R-IA) * [[Randy Neugebauer]] (R-TX) * [[Michael D. Rogers]] (R-Ala.) * [[Mike Conaway]] (R-TX) * [[Glenn Thompson (politician)|Glenn Thompson]] (R-PA) * [[Austin Scott (politician)|Austin Scott]] (R-GA) * [[Rick Crawford (politician)|Rick Crawford]] (R-AR) * [[Martha Roby]] (R-Ala.) * [[Kristi Noem]] (R-SD) * [[Jeff Denham]] (R-CA) * [[Rodney Davis (politician)|Rodney Davis]] (R-Ill.) * [[Collin Peterson]] (D-MN) * [[Mike McIntyre]] (D-NC) * [[Jim Costa]] (D-CA) * [[Tim Walz]] (D-MN) * [[Kurt Schrader]] (D-Ore.) * [[Jim McGovern (American politician)|Jim McGovern]] (D-MA) * [[Suzan DelBene]] (D-WA) * [[Gloria Negrete McLeod]] (D-CA) * [[Filemon Vela, Jr.]] (D-TX)<ref name="2642allactions"/>
On January 27, 2014, the [http://beta.congress.gov/113/crpt/hrpt333/CRPT-113hrpt333.pdf Conference Committee report] was released. On January 29, 2014, the House voted 251-166 to pass the bill.<ref name=Hpass956B>{{cite news|title=House passes $956B farm bill|url=http://thehill.com/blogs/floor-action/house/196819-house-passes-956b-farm-bill|accessdate=29 January 2014|newspaper=The Hill|date=29 January 2014|author=Pete Kasperowicz|author2=Erik Wasson}}</ref> In the House, a majority of Republicans voted in favor of the bill (163-62) and the Democrats split almost evenly (89-103).<ref name="bernstein29"/> The Senate then voted 68–32 on February 4, 2014, to approve the full five-year farm bill, sending it to President [[Barack Obama]] to be signed into law.<ref name=passed>{{cite news|last=Rogers|first=David|title=Congress approves five-year farm bill|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2014/02/congress-approves-farm-bill-103114.html?hp=t1_3|accessdate=4 February 2014|newspaper=Politico|date=4 February 2014}}</ref><ref name=finalvote>{{cite web|title=U.S. Senate Roll Call Votes 113th Congress - 2nd Session|url=https://www.senate.gov/legislative/LIS/roll_call_lists/roll_call_vote_cfm.cfm?congress=113&session=2&vote=00021|publisher=United States Senate|accessdate=4 February 2014}}</ref>
==Debate and discussion== Both Speaker of the House [[John Boehner]] and Majority Leader [[Eric Cantor]] supported the bill and asked other Republicans to do so.<ref name="nytNixonHapproves"/> However, both men indicated they would have preferred additional changes.<ref name="nytNixonHapproves"/>
On January 29, 2014, after passage in the House, it was considered "unclear" what President Obama thought of the farm bill because he had previously "signaled his opposition to any bill that cut food stamps and expanded crop insurance."<ref name="nytNixonHapproves"/>
[[Feeding America]] said that the cuts to food stamps would "result in 34 lost meals per month for the affected households."<ref name="nytNixonHapproves"/>

[[File:Photograph of First Lady Bess Truman at the White House with a delegation of Girl Scouts, who are presenting her with... - NARA - 200404.jpg|thumb|200px|American First Lady [[Bess Truman]] with [[Girl Guides|Girl Scouts]] and their volunteer leaders]] An '''avocation''' is an activity that someone engages in as a hobby outside their main occupation. There are many examples of people whose professions were the ways that they made their livings, but for whom their activities outside their workplaces were their true passions in life.{{cite web |url= http://dragonintuitive.com/avocation-vs-vocation/ |title= Avocation-vs-vocation |author= Travis Saunders |date= |work= |publisher= |accessdate=10 February 2011}}{{cite web |url= http://www.newstimes.com/news/article/Your-avocation-may-save-your-life-373723.php |title= Your avocation may save your life. |author= Robert Miller |date= 10 February 2010 |work= The News-Times |publisher= Hearst Corporation |accessdate=10 February 2011}} Occasionally, as with [[Robert Baden-Powell, 1st Baron Baden-Powell|Lord Baden-Powell]] and others, people who pursue an avocation are more remembered by history for their avocation than for their professional career. Many times a person's regular vocation may lead to an avocation. Many forms of humanitarian campaigning, such as work for organizations like [[Amnesty International]] and [[Greenpeace]], may be done by people involved in the law or human rights issues as part of their work.{{cite news |last= Boyd |first= B |date=20 October 2006 |title=A secret history of the old Ball game. | url= http://www.irishtimes.com/culture/revolver-1.1018425 |newspaper=Irish Times |access-date=2007-07-04 }} Many people involved with youth work pursue this as an avocation.{{cite web |url= http://www.bowdoin.edu/bowdoinmagazine/archives/features/002157.shtml |title= Avocation in Wood |author= Craig Giammona |date= |work= Bowdoin |publisher= |accessdate=10 February 2011}} {{compact ToC |seealso=yes|extlinks=yes|refs=yes|custom1 =Fictional people|custom1link=Avocation#Fictional people whose avocations were not their vocations|pre1=Avocation in literature |top=no |prebreak=yes |pre2=People whose avocations were not their vocations}} ==Avocation in literature== {{quote|But yield who will to their separation,
My object in living is to unite
My avocation and my vocation
As my two eyes make one in sight.
Only where love and need are one,
And the work is play for mortal stakes,
Is the deed ever really done
For heaven and the future's sakes.|[[Robert Frost]]|Two Tramps in Mud Time, st. 9}} ==People whose avocations were not their vocations== ===A=== [[File:Ambros August Wilhelm 1862.jpg|thumb|100px|right|[[August Wilhelm Ambros]]]] {| border=1 cellpadding=2 cellspacing=0 width=75% |- style="background:#efefef" ! width=30% | Person !
